author: VNExplorer
title: FGR detiene 3 militares del caso Ayotzinapa acusa de Delincuencia Organizada
text:
Tres de las ocho órdenes, se ejecutaron este medio día, cuando el personal castrense acudió a firmar a la Unidad de Medidas Cautelares del Penal de Máxima seguridad del Altiplano en el Estado de México.
Elementos de la Policía Federal Ministerial (PFM) de la Fiscalía General de la República (FGR) cumplimentaron tres órdenes de aprehensión contra tres elementos de la Secretaría de la Defensa Nacional que habían sido liberados hace una semana por la juez Raquel Ivette Duarte Cedillo, quien les otorgó el beneficio de la libertad condicional.
De acuerdo con fuentes del Consejo de la Judicatura Federal (CJF), un Juez de Procesos liberó ocho órdenes de aprehensión por el delito de delincuencia organizada contra los ocho militares involucrados en el caso de los estudiantes desaparecidos de Ayotzinapa.
Tres de las ocho órdenes, se ejecutaron este medio día, cuando el personal castrense acudió a firmar a la Unidad de Medidas Cautelares del Penal de Máxima seguridad del Altiplano en el Estado de México.
La defensa a cargo del abogado Alejandro Robledo Carretero, acudirá en las próximas horas ante el juzgado federal que libró las órdenes de aprehensión para conocer la acusación, que es por el delito de por supuestos vínculos con el grupo criminal Guerreros Unidos.
“Es una porquería del gobierno federal lo que están haciendo, es una chicana muy barata, no se puede esperar menos de ellos, pero la vamos a enfrentar la vamos a ganar. Lo que no pueden ganar por las buenas en el derecho lo pretenden hacer manipulando el derecho, esa es la verdad”.
Cabe recordar que el pasado 24 de enero del presente año, la juez Raquel Ivette Duarte Cedillo les otorgó el beneficio de la libertad condicional a Gustavo Rodríguez de la Cruz, Omar Torres Marquillo, Juan Andrés Flores Lagunes, Ramiro Manzanares Sanabria, Roberto de los Santos Eduviges, Eloy Estrada Díaz, Uri Yashiel Reyes Lazos y Juan Sotelo Díaz para seguir su proceso penal por el delito de desaparición forzada.
De acuerdo con fuentes de la FGR, será en las próximas horas cuando sean cumplimentadas las restantes cinco órdenes, e incluso se contempla que su abogado defensor promueva un amparo para evitar la detención y presentarlos ante el juzgado correspondiente.
*LDH*

author: webdev
title: Boeing Factory Staff Reject Contract, Will Walk at Midnight
text:
(Bloomberg) — Boeing Co. factory workers are poised to walk off the job, crippling manufacturing across the planemaker’s Seattle commercial jet hub after members of its largest union rejected a contract offer and voted to strike.
Most Read from Bloomberg
The walkout, from midnight Friday Seattle time, is the first since 2008 by the district of the International Association of Machinists And Aerospace Workers representing 33,000 Boeing employees across the US West Coast.
It adds to the strain on the planemaker, already reeling from the fallout over quality lapses after a near-catastrophe at the start of 2024 that spurred investigations, a customer revolt and an executive shake-up.
“This has been a long time coming, our members spoke loud and clear tonight,” Jon Holden, president of IAM District 751, said to a packed hall of union members and media. “Clearly there were aspects of this agreement that weren’t good enough.” By the time he’d finished speaking, the chants of ‘strike, strike’ were deafening.
Members voted overwhelmingly to strike, with 94.6% voting to reject the offer and 96% supporting a strike, ignoring a plea for peace by new Boeing Chief Executive Officer Kelly Ortberg, who has vowed to reset labor relations. And they bucked the recommendation of their own union leaders that they accept terms that included a 25% guaranteed wage increase over four years. While that’s the largest such pay hike ever offered by the planemaker, workers had expected a far greater increase. They were also angered that the terms also eliminated an annual bonus.
Boeing has been in a financially difficult situation since a Jan. 5 accident exposed deficiencies at its factories and forced the planemaker to reduce production. The company has been bleeding cash as a result, and its credit rating is hovering one step above speculative grade, putting the planemaker in a difficult position as it contends with a heavy debt load of $45 billion.
The defeat at the hand of workers means that Boeing and IAM District 751 will need to head back to the negotiating table to try and find terms that satisfy members of a union with a long history of activism. Cai von Rumohr, an analyst at TD Cowen, has estimated the walk-out could run for more than 50 days, in line with previous strikes, clipping between $3 billion and $3.5 billion from Boeing’s cash flow.
Starting in about two hours, Boeing workers will man picket lines at about 30 company gates from California to Moses Lake, in eastern Washington.
Because the union is claiming an unfair labor practices strike, a mediator will be assigned by the federal National Labor Relations Board, Holden said. No talks are scheduled as yet. And as union leader, Holden wants to first canvass workers to hone in on their top priorities.
Boeing has said its offer was the best it could put forward given its strained finances. The company hasn’t said how it would respond, but managers have been canvassing other workers this week to see if they have the skills to temporarily replace striking IAM members.
In the lead up to the late-night decision, IAM members outside of Boeing’s Renton factory, where it builds 737 Max jetliners, voiced their anger at the offer and described the frustration of seeing wages stagnate under a long-term deal struck in 2014 that also eliminated pensions.
They’re also mad the company kept a provision that forces hourly workers to be on the job for six years before they reach the maximum pay categories.
“I’m working stupid amounts of overtime just to get by,” said Zachary Haley, a 737 quality assurance inspector who’s been with Boeing for five years.
–With assistance from Danny Lee.
(Updates with union president in 4th paragraph, context throughout.)
